entries.title: Google and Apple fall short on earnings while Amazon beats expectations
entries.description: The world's biggest tech companies posted their earnings after several weeks of unprecedented layoff rounds in the usually unassailable tech sector amid pessimism about the economic outlook.

entries.title: Israel and Sundan agree to normalize relations and work toward a peace agreement
entries.description: Israel's Foreign Minister Eli Cohen said he expects relations to be formalised by the end of the year.

entries.title: In Japan, 'while the level of income inequality is higher than the OECD average, the perception of it is lower.'
entries.description: Low demand for redistribution mainly results from the fact that Japanese youth, who include Japan's most economically disadvantaged population, have given up on changing society.

entries.title: Transgender woman's prison transfer sparks controversy in Scotland
entries.description: The government declined to get involved in the case involving a transgender woman convicted of two rapes prior to her transition, leading to the suspension of the transfer.

entries.title: Iranian Kurds find a semblance of security in exile: 'At least we didn't bow down to injustice'
entries.description: Many young Iranian Kurds who took part in the protest movement are now refugees in Iraqi Kurdistan, but they are still recovering from their wounds, both physical and psychological.

entries.title: French pension reform: PM Borne comes under pressure
entries.description: Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne is facing growing pressure after large protests showed there was a strong opposition to raising the retirement age.

entries.title: Paris trial seeks answers on mysterious assault of Thai political refugee Aum Neko
entries.description: A Czech man accused of organizing a violent intimidation operation in Paris against a Thai political refugee appeared before the Paris Court of Appeal on February 1, 2023.

entries.title: Spain and Morocco seek reconciliation, with significant compromises
entries.description: The first summit in eight years between Spain and Morocco is being held following Madrid's acceptance of Rabat's policy in the Western Sahara.

entries.title: Mbappé will miss first leg of PSG Champions League tie against Bayern Munich
entries.description: Kylian Mbappé suffered a thigh injury in a Ligue 1 match against Montpellier, and will be out for three weeks.

entries.title: Ukraine looks to clear corruption obstacles from long road to EU membership
entries.description: Ukraine held anti-corruption raids on Wednesday, February 1, prior to the arrival of European Union representatives. The fight against corruption will be crucial if it wants to join the EU bloc.

entries.title: European Central Bank hikes key rates by further 0.5 points
entries.description: The bank raised its key rates by half a percentage point and said it will 'stay the course' in its monetary policy tightening.

entries.title: Marina Abramovic's extreme performance art in two documentaries
entries.description: The Serbian artist is the subject of films on Netflix and Arte.tv, one focused on her collaboration with Bob Wilson and the other on a questionable method that bears her name.

entries.title: French immigration bill: The return of the 'immigrant worker'
entries.description: The issue of work has made a welcome return in a debate too often monopolized by questions of security or identity.

entries.title: France's Raphaël Varane announces international retirement, at 29
entries.description: The Manchester United defender won the World Cup with France in 2018 and lost in the final of the 2022 edition.

entries.title: EU eyes new Russia sanctions by end-month
entries.description: Existing sanctions cost Russia €160 million a day, according to EU Commission chief Ursula Von der Leyen who is visiting Kyiv on Thursday.

entries.title: European Parliament lifts immunity of two members in suspected bribery probe
entries.description: Marc Tarabella and Andrea Cozzolino are both under investigation from Belgian authorities over suspected corruption linked to Qatar and Morocco.

entries.title: Algerian regime escalates repression by shutting down human rights organization
entries.description: Algiers is working to eliminate the remaining core behind the 2019 Hirak protest movement.

entries.title: From Donetsk to Kyiv, the tribulations of a lost soldier
entries.description: In the black-and-white world of war, Vladyslav L. belongs to a gray zone. Enlisted at 18 in the pro-Russian forces in the Donbas in 2014, he later tried to join the Ukrainian army and now faces charges of 'involvement in a terrorist group.'

entries.title: New director of the Beaux-Arts de Paris: 'The issue of diversity in recruitment is fundamental'
entries.description: In an interview with 'Le Monde', the head of the institution outlines her plans for her school, which is facing numerous architectural and pedagogical challenges.

entries.title: Constitutional right to abort: Eyes are on French government after Sénat votes in favor
entries.description: Senators agreed on 'the freedom of a woman to terminate her pregnancy.' If MPs approve the wording, the bill could be submitted to a referendum. But proponents want a government bill, which would avoid going to the polls.

entries.title: France seizes military equipment headed to Yemen
entries.description: The seizure of thousands of assault rifles, machine guns and anti-tank missiles took place on January 15 in the Gulf of Oman.

entries.title: Indian billionaire Adani cancels landmark public offering as his group falls apart
entries.description: Adani Group's shares continued to plummet on Thursday, February 2, after the abrupt announcement of the cancellation of a historic fundraising effort and accusations of fraud.

entries.title: 'The arms industry can wait calmly for the dividends of the war in Ukraine'
entries.description: Kyiv's requests for military equipment are pouring in, and supply is struggling to keep up. Still, shortages will not constrain the arms industry for much longer as Western rearmament picks up speed, writes Jean-Michel Bezat for 'Le Monde'.

entries.title: Gabriel Tacchino, leading French classical pianist, has died
entries.description: The French pianist, who made the first complete recording of the piano compositions of Francis Poulenc, whom he was close to, died on January 29, 2023, at 88.

entries.title: 'For the US and the Europeans, the goal of a Palestinian state has become a secondary'
entries.description: The current momentum leans more than ever toward territorial unification, with different rights for the Palestinian and Israeli populations, writes 'Le Monde' columnist Gilles Paris.

entries.title: US to step up military presence in the Philippines
entries.description: The agreement, made public as Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin visits Manila, comes amid heightened tensions in the South China Sea.

entries.title: ChatGPT: 'Integrating advanced language models will not hinder the comprehension of the humanities and social sciences'
entries.description: Researcher Bernardino León-Reyes argues it is time to stop worrying about the use of artificial intelligence in education, and focus on how it can enhance and help creativity.

entries.title: Pope Francis visits the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo to deliver message of peace and hope
entries.description: On Wednesday afternoon, the Pope met with internally displaced persons from the large eastern region of the DRC where a hundred armed groups currently operate, including the M23 rebel group.

entries.title: EU representatives visit Kyiv to boost morale as Ukraine eyes membership
entries.description: The first EU-Ukraine summit since the start of the war will be held on Friday, February 3.

entries.title: North Korea warns of 'overwhelming nuclear force' as US and S. Korea hold military drills
entries.description: South Korea’s Defense Ministry said the United States flew B-1B bombers and F-22 and F-35 fighter jets in an exercise with South Korean fighters on Wednesday above South Korea’s western waters in their latest show of strength.

entries.title: The pension reform, a symbol of Macron's faltering political narrative
entries.description: The project was supposed to prove French President Emmanuel Macron's ability to transform the country, but communication on the matter has been chaotic.

entries.title: In the Himalayas, India remains under increasing threat from China
entries.description: As tensions escalate in the Himalayan standoff between the two most populous countries, China has the advantage as India faces the dilemma of a war on two fronts.

entries.title: Australia will remove British monarchs from its banknotes
entries.description: The Australian central bank decided to replace the late Queen Elizabeth II's image on its $5 note with a design honouring Indigenous culture.

entries.title: The foreign press shares their opinion on French pension reform
entries.description: For the international media, the success of the second day of inter-union demonstrations is a strong warning message to the government.

entries.title: Canada experiments with decriminalization of 'hard' drugs
entries.description: Strongly impacted by the opioid crisis that is ravaging North America, British Columbia will no longer prosecute those who possess a few grams of opiates.

entries.title: Biden administration recommends major oil project in Alaska
entries.description: The move – while not final – drew immediate anger from environmentalists who saw it as a betrayal of the president's pledges to reduce carbon emissions and promote clean energy sources.
